head.title: Resonances and Chaos in the Collective Oscillations of a Trapped Bose Condensate

article.h1: Resonances and Chaos in the Collective Oscillations of a Trapped Bose Condensate

span.span:
Istituto Nazionale per la Fisica della Materia, UnitÃ di Milano,
Dipartimento di Fisica, UniversitÃ di Milano,
Via Celoria 16, 20133 Milano, Italy

div.p: We investigate the collective oscillations of a Bose condensate in an anisotropic harmonic trap. We analytically calculate the values of the trap deformation for which the normal modes are in resonance. In presence of low-order resonances, the amplitude dependence of frequencies is strongly enhanced. We also study the transition to chaos of the collective modes as a function of the trap anisotropy.

The Bose-Einstein condensation (BEC) is the macroscopic occupation of the single-particle ground-state of a system of bosons. In the 1995 BEC has been achieved with dilute vapors of confined alkali-metal atoms.1-313FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{1-3} The experiments with alkali-metal atoms generally consist of a laser cooling and confinement in an external potential (magnetic or magneto-optical trap) and an evaporative cooling.1-313FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{1-3} Nowadays a dozen of experimental groups have obtained Bose condensates by using different atomic species and geometries of the confining trap.

The theoretically predicted low-energy collective oscillations of the Bose condensate44FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{4} have been experimentally confirmed by laser imaging techniques.55FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{5} Moreover, the dynamics of the collective oscillations of the condensate has been theoretically studied beyond the linear regime, showing strong enhancement of the amplitude dependence of frequencies in presence of resonances.66FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{6}

In this paper we derive analytical formulas that give the values of trap anisotropy for which the normal modes of the collective oscillations are in resonance. We discuss also the transition to chaos of the collective modes by increasing the energy of the system, namely by considering oscillations of very large amplitude. Note that the chaoticity of the high-energy single-particle excitations of the condensate has been shown in the classical limit by Fliesser et al.77FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:7 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{7} Here, we consider instead the low-energy collective excitations: they have a classical-like behavior but satisfy the quantum mechanical equations of a superfluid in an external potential.44FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{4}

In current experiments alkali vapors are quite dilute and at zero temperature the atoms are practically all in the condensate.1-313FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{1-3} The dynamics of the Bose condensate can be accurately described by the Gross-Pitaevskii (GP) equation88FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{8} of mean-field approximation

math.alttext: i\hbar{\partial\over\partial t}\phi({\bf r},t)=\left[-{\hbar^{2}\over 2m}% \nabla^{2}+U({\bf r})+g|\phi({\bf r},t)|^{2}\right]\phi({\bf r},t)\;,

semantics.annotation: italic-i ID:Planck-constant-over-2-pi FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start OPERATOR:partial-differential ARG:end ARG:start OPERATOR:partial-differential italic-t ARG:end italic-phi OPEN:( bold-r PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals OPEN:[ ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start ID:Planck-constant-over-2-pi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 italic-m ARG:end OPERATOR:nabla POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-U OPEN:( bold-r CLOSE:) ADDOP:plus italic-g VERTBAR:| italic-phi OPEN:( bold-r PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) VERTBAR:| POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:] italic-phi OPEN:( bold-r PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) PUNCT:,
i\hbar{\partial\over\partial t}\phi({\bf r},t)=\left[-{\hbar^{2}\over 2m}% \nabla^{2}+U({\bf r})+g|\phi({\bf r},t)|^{2}\right]\phi({\bf r},t)\;,

div.p: where Ï•â¢(ğ«,t)italic-Ï•ğ«ğ‘¡italic-phi OPEN:( bold-r PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)\phi({\bf r},t) is the macroscopic wavefunction (order parameter) of the condensate, normalized to the number Nğ‘italic-NN of condensed atoms. The external trap is well approximated by an anisotropic harmonic potential

semantics.annotation: italic-U OPEN:( bold-r CLOSE:) RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-m ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end OPEN:( italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-y POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) PERIOD:.

div.p: and the parameter of the nonlinear term g=4â¢Ï€â¢â„2â¢as/mğ‘”4ğœ‹superscriptPlanck-constant-over-2-pi2subscriptğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘šitalic-g RELOP:equals NUMBER:4 italic-pi ID:Planck-constant-over-2-pi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-mg={4\pi\hbar^{2}a_{s}/m} is the scattering amplitude with assubscriptğ‘ğ‘ italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:enda_{s} the s-wave scattering length. It is useful to introduce the geometric average Ï‰h=(Ï‰1â¢Ï‰2â¢Ï‰3)1/3subscriptğœ”â„superscriptsubscriptğœ”1subscriptğœ”2subscriptğœ”313italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals OPEN:( italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\omega_{h}=(\omega_{1}\omega_{2}\omega_{3})^{1/3} of the trap frequencies and the characteristic length ah=(â„/mâ¢Ï‰h)1/2subscriptğ‘â„superscriptPlanck-constant-over-2-piğ‘šsubscriptğœ”â„12italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals OPEN:( ID:Planck-constant-over-2-pi MULOP:divide italic-m italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:enda_{h}=(\hbar/m\omega_{h})^{1/2} of the trap. In previous papers we have studied the properties of the Bose condensate with attractive interaction, in particular for 77FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:7 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{7}Li atoms.9,10910FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:9 PUNCT:, NUMBER:10 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{9,10} Here, instead, we consider only the case of a repulsive interaction.
The complex wavefunction Ï•â¢(ğ«,t)italic-Ï•ğ«ğ‘¡italic-phi OPEN:( bold-r PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)\phi({\bf r},t) of the condensate can be written in terms of a modulus and a phase, as follows

semantics.annotation: italic-phi OPEN:( bold-r PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-square-root ARG:start italic-rho OPEN:( bold-r PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) ARG:end italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i italic-S OPEN:( bold-r PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PERIOD:.

div.p: The phase Sğ‘†italic-SS fixes the velocity field ğ¯=(â„/m)â¢âˆ‡â¡Sğ¯Planck-constant-over-2-piğ‘šâˆ‡ğ‘†bold-v RELOP:equals OPEN:( ID:Planck-constant-over-2-pi MULOP:divide italic-m CLOSE:) OPERATOR:nabla italic-S{\bf v}=(\hbar/m)\nabla S. The GP equation can hence be rewritten in the form of two coupled hydrodynamic equations for the density and the velocity field.44FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{4} If the repulsive interaction among atoms is strong enough, i.e. Nâ¢as/ahâ‰«1much-greater-thanğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘ subscriptğ‘â„1italic-N italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:much-greater-than NUMBER:1Na_{s}/a_{h}>>1, then one can safely neglect the kinetic pressure term in the equation for the velocity field. In this way, the hydrodynamic equations read

semantics.annotation: FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start OPERATOR:partial-differential ARG:end ARG:start OPERATOR:partial-differential italic-t ARG:end italic-rho ADDOP:plus OPERATOR:nabla MULOP:cdot OPEN:( bold-v italic-rho CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:0 PUNCT:,

italic-m FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start OPERATOR:partial-differential ARG:end ARG:start OPERATOR:partial-differential italic-t ARG:end bold-v ADDOP:plus OPERATOR:nabla OPEN:( italic-U ADDOP:plus italic-g italic-rho ADDOP:plus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-m italic-v POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:0 PERIOD:.

div.p: These equations are those of a superfluid in an external potential.44FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{4} The ground-state solution (ğ¯=0ğ¯0bold-v RELOP:equals NUMBER:0{\bf v}=0) of the hydrodynamic equations is Ïâ¢(ğ«)=g-1â¢[Î¼-Uâ¢(ğ«)]ğœŒğ«superscriptğ‘”1delimited-[]ğœ‡ğ‘ˆğ«italic-rho OPEN:( bold-r CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-g POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:[ italic-mu ADDOP:minus italic-U OPEN:( bold-r CLOSE:) CLOSE:]\rho({\bf r})=g^{-1}\left[\mu-U({\bf r})\right], in the region where Î¼>Uâ¢(ğ«)ğœ‡ğ‘ˆğ«italic-mu RELOP:greater-than italic-U OPEN:( bold-r CLOSE:)\mu>U({\bf r}), and Ï=0ğœŒ0italic-rho RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\rho=0 outside. The normalization condition on Ïâ¢(ğ«)ğœŒğ«italic-rho OPEN:( bold-r CLOSE:)\rho({\bf r}) provides Î¼=(â„â¢Ï‰h/2)â¢(15â¢Nâ¢as/ah)2/5ğœ‡Planck-constant-over-2-pisubscriptğœ”â„2superscript15ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘ subscriptğ‘â„25italic-mu RELOP:equals OPEN:( ID:Planck-constant-over-2-pi italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) OPEN:( NUMBER:15 italic-N italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 MULOP:divide NUMBER:5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\mu=(\hbar\omega_{h}/2)(15Na_{s}/a_{h})^{2/5}.

An analytic class of solutions of Eq. (4) has been found found by Dalfovo et al.66FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{6} writing the density in the form Ïâ¢(ğ«,t)=a0â¢(t)-a1â¢(t)â¢x2-a2â¢(t)â¢y2-a3â¢(t)â¢z2ğœŒğ«ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘0ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘1ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¥2subscriptğ‘2ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¦2subscriptğ‘3ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘§2italic-rho OPEN:( bold-r PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) ADDOP:minus italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) italic-y POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\rho({\bf r},t)=a_{0}(t)-a_{1}(t)x^{2}-a_{2}(t)y^{2}-a_{3}(t)z^{2} in the region where Ïâ¢(ğ«,t)ğœŒğ«ğ‘¡italic-rho OPEN:( bold-r PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)\rho({\bf r},t) is positive, and the velocity field as ğ¯â¢(ğ«,t)=12â¢âˆ‡â¡[b1â¢(t)â¢x2+b2â¢(t)â¢y2+b3â¢(t)â¢z2]ğ¯ğ«ğ‘¡12âˆ‡subscriptğ‘1ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¥2subscriptğ‘2ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¦2subscriptğ‘3ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘§2bold-v OPEN:( bold-r PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end OPERATOR:nabla OPEN:[ italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) italic-x POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) italic-y POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:]{\bf v}({\bf r},t)={1\over 2}\nabla[b_{1}(t)x^{2}+b_{2}(t)y^{2}+b_{3}(t)z^{2}]. The coefficient a0subscriptğ‘0italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:enda_{0} is fixed by the normalization of the density a0=(15â¢N/8â¢Ï€)2/5â¢(a1â¢a2â¢a3)1/5subscriptğ‘0superscript15ğ‘8ğœ‹25superscriptsubscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2subscriptğ‘315italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals OPEN:( NUMBER:15 italic-N MULOP:divide NUMBER:8 italic-pi CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 MULOP:divide NUMBER:5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:enda_{0}=(15N/8\pi)^{2/5}(a_{1}a_{2}a_{3})^{1/5}. By inserting these expressions in the hydrodynamic equations one finds 6 coupled differential equations for the time-dependent parameters aiâ¢(t)subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘¡italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)a_{i}(t) and biâ¢(t)subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘¡italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)b_{i}(t). By introducing new variables qisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:endq_{i}, defined by ai=mâ¢Ï‰i2â¢(2â¢gâ¢qi2â¢q1â¢q2â¢q3)-1subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğœ”ğ‘–2superscript2ğ‘”superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–2subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2subscriptğ‘31italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-m italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( NUMBER:2 italic-g italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:enda_{i}=m\omega_{i}^{2}(2gq_{i}^{2}q_{1}q_{2}q_{3})^{-1}, the hydrodynamic equations give bi=qË™i/qisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptË™ğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals OVERACCENT:dot ARG:start italic-q ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:endb_{i}={\dot{q}_{i}}/q_{i} and

div.p: with i=1,2,3ğ‘–123italic-i RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:2 PUNCT:, NUMBER:3i=1,2,3. It is important to observe that, using the new variables qisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:endq_{i}, the equations of motion do not depend on the value of the coupling constant gğ‘”italic-gg. In terms of qisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:endq_{i} the mean square radii of the condensate are <xi2â‰¥(2â¢Î¼/mâ¢Ï‰i)â¢qi2absentsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–22ğœ‡ğ‘šsubscriptğœ”ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–2RELOP:less-than italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than-or-equals OPEN:( NUMBER:2 italic-mu MULOP:divide italic-m italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end<x_{i}^{2}>=(2\mu/m\omega_{i})q_{i}^{2} and the velocities are <vi2â‰¥(2â¢Î¼/mâ¢Ï‰i)â¢qË™i2absentsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–22ğœ‡ğ‘šsubscriptğœ”ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptË™ğ‘ğ‘–2RELOP:less-than italic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than-or-equals OPEN:( NUMBER:2 italic-mu MULOP:divide italic-m italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) OVERACCENT:dot ARG:start italic-q ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end<v_{i}^{2}>=(2\mu/m\omega_{i}){\dot{q}}_{i}^{2} (see also Ref. 6).
The Eq. (5) are the classical equations of motion of a system with coordinates qisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:endq_{i} and Lagrangian given by

semantics.annotation: italic-L RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OVERACCENT:dot ARG:start italic-q ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end PERIOD:.

div.p: This Lagrangian describes the collective modes of the Bose condensate for Nâ¢as/ahâ‰«1much-greater-thanğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘ subscriptğ‘â„1italic-N italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:much-greater-than NUMBER:1Na_{s}/a_{h}>>1. In such a case the collective dynamics of the condensate does not depend on the number of atoms or the scattering length. The low-energy collective excitations of the condensate are the small oscillations of variables qisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:endq_{i}â€™s around the equilibrium point, i.e. the minimum of the effective potential âˆ‘i=13qi2+1/(q1â¢q2â¢q3)superscriptsubscriptğ‘–13superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–21subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2subscriptğ‘3SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide OPEN:( italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\sum_{i=1}^{3}q_{i}^{2}+1/(q_{1}q_{2}q_{3}). The normal mode frequencies Î©Î©Omega\Omega of the condensate are given by the following equation

semantics.annotation: Omega POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 OPEN:( italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) Omega POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus NUMBER:8 OPEN:( italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) Omega POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus NUMBER:20 italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0 PERIOD:.

div.p: Note that this formula has been recently obtained by using a variational approach1111FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:11 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{11} and also by studying hydrodynamic density fluctuations of the condensate.1212FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:12 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{12} For an axially symmetric trap, where Ï‰1=Ï‰2=Ï‰âŠ¥subscriptğœ”1subscriptğœ”2subscriptğœ”bottomitalic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:bottom POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\omega_{1}=\omega_{2}=\omega_{\bot}, the previous equation gives

semantics.annotation: Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-square-root ARG:start NUMBER:2 ADDOP:plus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:3 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end italic-lambda POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus-or-minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end italic-square-root ARG:start NUMBER:16 ADDOP:plus NUMBER:9 italic-lambda POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus NUMBER:16 italic-lambda POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:end italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:bottom POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:,
Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-square-root ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:bottom POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:,

div.p: where Î»=Ï‰3/Ï‰âŠ¥ğœ†subscriptğœ”3subscriptğœ”bottomitalic-lambda RELOP:equals italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:bottom POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\lambda=\omega_{3}/\omega_{\bot} is the anisotropy parameter of the trap. The frequencies Î©1,2subscriptÎ©12Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Omega_{1,2} are the mz=0subscriptğ‘šğ‘§0italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0m_{z}=0 monopole and quadrupole modes, where mzsubscriptğ‘šğ‘§italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{z} is the third component of the angular momentum. Instead the frequency Î©3subscriptÎ©3Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Omega_{3} is the mz=2subscriptğ‘šğ‘§2italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:2m_{z}=2 quadrupole mode.44FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{4} It is important to observe that the experimental results obtained with sodium vapors at MIT (Î»=8ğœ†8italic-lambda RELOP:equals italic-square-root ARG:start NUMBER:8 ARG:end\lambda=\sqrt{8}) are in good agreement with these theoretical values.1313FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:13 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{13}

The normal modes are functions of the trap frequencies, i.e. of the trap deformation. Beyond the linear regime there is a strong enhancement of nonlinear effects when frequencies of different modes, or of their harmonics, coincide, i.e. when the normal modes are in resonance.6,14614FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6 PUNCT:, NUMBER:14 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{6,14} By using a perturbative approach, Dalfovo et al.66FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{6} have identified 3 resonant values of the trap anisotropy. For such values, the numerical solution of Eq. (5) shows that the collective frequencies deviate from the predictions of Eq. (7) or (8) also for small amplitude oscillations.
To find the BEC resonances we use a different and new strategy. In general, the resonance condition is given by

semantics.annotation: italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0 PUNCT:,

div.p: where (n1,n2,n3)âˆˆğ™3\{ğŸ}subscriptğ‘›1subscriptğ‘›2subscriptğ‘›3\superscriptğ™30OPEN:( italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:element-of bold-Z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:backslash OPEN:{ NUMBER:bold-0 CLOSE:}(n_{1},n_{2},n_{3})\in{\bf Z}^{3}\backslash\{{\bf 0}\} is a non-zero vector of integer numbers and R=|n1|+|n2|+|n3|ğ‘…subscriptğ‘›1subscriptğ‘›2subscriptğ‘›3italic-R RELOP:equals VERTBAR:| italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| ADDOP:plus VERTBAR:| italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| ADDOP:plus VERTBAR:| italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:|R=|n_{1}|+|n_{2}|+|n_{3}| is the order of the resonance. It is possible to numerically determine the values of the trap deformation for which the resonance condition is satisfied. Nevertheless, because in most experiments the confining trap has axial symmetry,1-313FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{1-3} one obtains remarkable analytical results from Eq. (8) and (9) by imposing that one of the integer numbers nisubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:endn_{i} is zero. In the case n1=0subscriptğ‘›10italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0n_{1}=0, the resonance condition (between a mz=0subscriptğ‘šğ‘§0italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0m_{z}=0 mode and the mz=2subscriptğ‘šğ‘§2italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:2m_{z}=2 mode) gives

semantics.annotation: italic-lambda RELOP:equals italic-square-root ARG:start FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:2 OPEN:( NUMBER:2 italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start OPEN:( NUMBER:5 italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:end PERIOD:.

div.p: In the case n2=0subscriptğ‘›20italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0n_{2}=0, one has the previous formula with n1subscriptğ‘›1italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endn_{1} instead of n2subscriptğ‘›2italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endn_{2}. Finally, in the case n3=0subscriptğ‘›30italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0n_{3}=0 one finds

semantics.annotation: italic-lambda RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:3 ARG:end italic-square-root ARG:start OPEN:[ NUMBER:5 OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ADDOP:plus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end CLOSE:) ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 CLOSE:] ADDOP:plus-or-minus italic-square-root ARG:start OPEN:[ NUMBER:5 OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ADDOP:plus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end CLOSE:) ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 CLOSE:] POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus NUMBER:144 ARG:end ARG:end PERIOD:.

div.p: This formula gives the anisotropy parameter at the resonance condition between the two mz=0subscriptğ‘šğ‘§0italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0m_{z}=0 modes.

In Table 1 are shown the values of the trap anisotropy Î»ğœ†italic-lambda\lambda for low-order resonances according to Eq. (10) and (11). Note that the values of Î»ğœ†italic-lambda\lambda for the (1,2,0)120OPEN:( NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:2 PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 CLOSE:)(1,2,0) and (0,1,2)012OPEN:( NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:2 CLOSE:)(0,1,2) resonances are that previously obtained by Dalfovo et al..66FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:6 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{6} As concerns resonances, the values of Î»ğœ†italic-lambda\lambda for the experimental traps of MIT (Î»=0.077ğœ†0.077italic-lambda RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.077\lambda=0.077) and JILA (Î»=8ğœ†8italic-lambda RELOP:equals italic-square-root ARG:start NUMBER:8 ARG:end\lambda=\sqrt{8}) are not of particular interest. Instead, it would be very interesting to study experimentally the system in the trap conditions given by Eq. (10) and (11). In fact, close to low-order resonances, even for relatively small amplitudes, the motion is rather complex and the dynamics can exhibit a chaotic-like behavior.1414FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:14 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{14}

One expects an order-chaos transition by increasing the amplitude of oscillations, thus by increasing the energy of the system with respect to the ground-state (minimum of the effective potential).1414FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:14 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{14} To check if such a scenario works in this context, we numerically study the chaotic dynamics of the mz=0subscriptğ‘šğ‘§0italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0m_{z}=0 modes (preliminar results can be found in Ref. 15). We put q1=q2=qâŠ¥subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2subscriptğ‘bottomitalic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:bottom POSTSUBSCRIPT:endq_{1}=q_{2}=q_{\bot} in the BEC lagrangian. By using the adimensional time Ï„=Ï‰âŠ¥â¢tğœsubscriptğœ”bottomğ‘¡italic-tau RELOP:equals italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:bottom POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-t\tau=\omega_{\bot}t, the BEC Hamiltonian of the mz=0subscriptğ‘šğ‘§0italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0m_{z}=0 collective modes reads

semantics.annotation: italic-H RELOP:equals italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:bottom POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end italic-lambda POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:bottom POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:bottom POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end PUNCT:,

div.p: where pâŠ¥=dâ¢qâŠ¥/dâ¢Ï„subscriptğ‘bottomğ‘‘subscriptğ‘bottomğ‘‘ğœitalic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:bottom POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-d italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:bottom POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-d italic-taup_{\bot}=dq_{\bot}/d\tau and p3=Î»-2â¢dâ¢q3/dâ¢Ï„subscriptğ‘3superscriptğœ†2ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘3ğ‘‘ğœitalic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-lambda POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-d italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-d italic-taup_{3}=\lambda^{-2}dq_{3}/d\tau are the conjugate momenta.1515FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:15 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{15} We use a symplectic method to numerically compute the trajectories. The conservation of energy restricts any trajectory of the four-dimensional phase space to a three-dimensional energy shell. At a particular energy, the restriction qâŠ¥=1subscriptğ‘bottom1italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:bottom POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1q_{\bot}=1 defines a two-dimensional surface in the phase space, that is called PoincarÃ¨ section. Each time a particular trajectory passes through the surface a point is plotted at the position of intersection (q3,p3)subscriptğ‘3subscriptğ‘3OPEN:( italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(q_{3},p_{3}). We employ a first-order interpolation process to reduce inaccuracies due to the use of a finite step length.

In Fig.1 and Fig. 2 we plot PoincarÃ¨ sections of the system with Î»=1.501ğœ†1.501italic-lambda RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.501\lambda=1.501 (corresponding to the (3,5,0)350OPEN:( NUMBER:3 PUNCT:, NUMBER:5 PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 CLOSE:)(3,5,0) resonance) and Î»=8ğœ†8italic-lambda RELOP:equals italic-square-root ARG:start NUMBER:8 ARG:end\lambda=\sqrt{8} (JILA experiment), respectively. In each panel there is a PoincarÃ¨ section with a fixed value of the energy of the system. At each energy value, we have chosen different initial conditions [qâŠ¥â¢(0)subscriptğ‘bottom0italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:bottom POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( NUMBER:0 CLOSE:)q_{\bot}(0),q3â¢(0)subscriptğ‘30italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( NUMBER:0 CLOSE:)q_{3}(0),pâŠ¥â¢(0)subscriptğ‘bottom0italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:bottom POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( NUMBER:0 CLOSE:)p_{\bot}(0),p3â¢(0)subscriptğ‘30italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( NUMBER:0 CLOSE:)p_{3}(0)] for the dynamics. Actually pâŠ¥â¢(0)subscriptğ‘bottom0italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:bottom POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( NUMBER:0 CLOSE:)p_{\bot}(0) has been fixed by the conservation of energy. Integration time is 400400NUMBER:400400 in adimensional units, that is less than 11NUMBER:11 second (the life-time of the condensate is about 1010NUMBER:1010 seconds). Chaotic regions on the PoincarÃ¨ section are characterized by a set of randomly distributed points and regular regions by dotted or solid curves.

We use the adimensional parameter Ï‡ğœ’italic-chi\chi, that is the relative increase of energy with respect to the ground-state. Fig. 1 shows that for Î»=1.501ğœ†1.501italic-lambda RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.501\lambda=1.501 there is an order-chaos transition by increasing Ï‡ğœ’italic-chi\chi: a chaotic sea appears at low energy (Ï‡=2/5ğœ’25italic-chi RELOP:equals NUMBER:2 MULOP:divide NUMBER:5\chi=2/5). On the contrary, Fig. 2 shows that for Î»=8ğœ†8italic-lambda RELOP:equals italic-square-root ARG:start NUMBER:8 ARG:end\lambda=\sqrt{8} at Ï‡=3/5ğœ’35italic-chi RELOP:equals NUMBER:3 MULOP:divide NUMBER:5\chi=3/5 the collective oscillations are inharmonic but still not chaotic.

To estimate the chaoticity of the mz=0subscriptğ‘šğ‘§0italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0m_{z}=0 modes, we calculate the fraction of initial conditions that give rise to regular trajectories. In the (Î»ğœ†italic-lambda\lambda,Ï‡ğœ’italic-chi\chi) plane we plot the configurations for which the mz=0subscriptğ‘šğ‘§0italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0m_{z}=0 oscillations are regular. The numerical results are shown in Fig. 3. As previously discussed, for Î»=1.501ğœ†1.501italic-lambda RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.501\lambda=1.501 (or Î»ğœ†italic-lambda\lambda very close to such a value) the system remains regular only at small Ï‡ğœ’italic-chi\chi; for larger Ï‡ğœ’italic-chi\chi it becomes gradually chaotic. In general, the transition to chaos depends on Ï‡ğœ’italic-chi\chi, but for Î»â‰ª1much-less-thanğœ†1italic-lambda RELOP:much-less-than NUMBER:1\lambda<<1 and Î»>4ğœ†4italic-lambda RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:4\lambda>4 the dynamics appears always regular. Actually, for Î»â‰ª1much-less-thanğœ†1italic-lambda RELOP:much-less-than NUMBER:1\lambda<<1 the system is integrable because of an additional constant of motion.1616FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:16 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{16} The MIT trap (Î»=0.077ğœ†0.077italic-lambda RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.077\lambda=0.077) belongs to this stable region.

We have analyzed the PoincarÃ¨ sections of the mz=0subscriptğ‘šğ‘§0italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0m_{z}=0 BEC Hamiltonian for all the resonant values of Î»ğœ†italic-lambda\lambda that are shown in Tab. 1 (left). Among the resonances, the (3,5,0)350OPEN:( NUMBER:3 PUNCT:, NUMBER:5 PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 CLOSE:)(3,5,0) resonance (Î»=0.888ğœ†0.888italic-lambda RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.888\lambda=0.888 and Î»=1.501ğœ†1.501italic-lambda RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.501\lambda=1.501) appears the most chaotic: this is the main prediction of our paper.

An important question is the following: can BEC chaotic dynamics be experimentally detected? The answer is positive. It is important to observe that, strictly speaking, there is no dynamical chaos in quantum systems with a finite number of degrees of freedom (for a discussion of chaos and quantum chaos in field theories see Ref. 17). Chaotic behaviour is possible only as a transient with lifetime tHsubscriptğ‘¡ğ»italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:endt_{H}, the so-called Heisenberg time.1818FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:18 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{18} Nevertheless, tHsubscriptğ‘¡ğ»italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:endt_{H} grows exponentially with the number of degrees of freedom and consequently the transient chaotic dynamics of quantum states and observables can be experimentally observed in Bose condensates.1919FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:19 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{19} Nowadays non-destructive images of the dynamics of the condensate can be obtained. The radius of the condensate as a function of time can be detected and its time evolution analyzed with great accuracy. Various initial conditions of the collective dynamics can be obtained by using laser beams or by modulating for a short period the magnetic fields which confine the condensate.

In conclusion, we have studied the collective oscillations of a Bose condensate in an anisotropic harmonic trap. We have found the values of trap deformation for which the normal modes of the collective oscillations are in resonance. For such values, nonlinear effects, like frequency shift and irregular patterns in the time evolution of the condensate shape, are strongly enhanced. We have analyzed the order-chaos transition of the mz=0subscriptğ‘šğ‘§0italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0m_{z}=0 collective oscillations by increasing the energy, namely the amplitude of oscillation. We have obtained compelling evidence that, for certain values of trap anisotropy, chaos is reached at very low energy.
We hope that our calculations may stimulate new measurements on the collective oscillations of Bose condensates in anisotropic traps.
The author thanks Prof. L. Reatto for useful suggestions.
1. M.H. Anderson, J.R. Ensher, M.R. Matthews, C.E. Wieman, and E.A. Cornell, Science 269, 189 (1995).
2. K.B. Davis, M.O. Mewes, M.R. Andrews, N.J. van Druten, D.S. Drufee, D.M. Stamper-Kurn, and W. Ketterle, Phys. Rev. Lett. 75, 3969 (1995).
3. C.C. Bradley, C.A. Sackett, J.J. Tollet, and R.G. Hulet, Phys. Rev. Lett. 75, 1687 (1995).
4. S. Stringari, Phys. Rev. Lett. 77, 2360 (1996).

5. D.S. Jin, J.R. Ensher, M.R. Matthews, C.E. Wieman, and E.A. Cornell, Phys. Rev. Lett. 77, 420 (1996); R. Onofrio, D.D. Durfee, C. Raman, M. Kohl, C.E. Kuklewicz, W. Ketterle, preprint cond-mat/9908340.
6. F. Dalfovo, C. Minniti, S. Stringari, and L. Pitaevskii, Phys. Lett. A 227, 259 (1997); F. Dalfovo, C. Minniti, and L. Pitaevskii, Phys. Rev. A 56, 4855 (1997).
7. M. Fliesser, A. Csordas, P. Szepfalusy, and R. Graham, Phys. Rev. A 56, R2533 (1997).
9. A. Parola, L. Salasnich, and L. Reatto, Phys. Rev. A 57, R3180 (1998); L. Reatto, A. Parola, and L. Salasnich, J. Low Temp. Phys. 113, 195 (1998).
11. E. Cerboneschi, R. Mannella, E. Arimondo, and L. Salasnich, Phys. Lett. A 249, 245 (1998).
12. S. Stringari, Phys. Rev. A 58 2385 (1998).
13. D.M. Stamper-Kurn, H.J. Miesner, S. Inouye, M.R. Andrews, and W. Ketterle, Phys. Rev. Lett. 81, 500 (1998).
14. A.J. Lichtenberg and M.A. Lieberman, Regular and Stochastic Motion (Springer, New York, 1983); V.I. Arnold, Mathematical Methods of Classical Mechanics (Moscow, Nauka, 1974).
15. L. Salasnich, preprint chao-dyn/9906034, to appear in Progr. Theor. Phys. Suppl., No. 139 (2000).
16. L.P. Pitaevskii, Phys. Lett. A 221, 14 (1996); L.P. Pitaevskii and A. Rosch, preprint cond-mat/9608135.
17. L. Salasnich, J. Math. Phys. 40, 4429 (1999).
18. V.R. Manfredi and L. Salasnich, in Perspectives on Theoretical Nuclear Physics VII, pp. 319-324, Ed. A. Fabrocini et al. (Edizioni ETS, Pisa, 1999).
19. V.R. Manfredi and L. Salasnich, Int. J. Mod. Phys. B 13, 2343 (1999).

div.p: Table 1. Low-order resonances of the normal modes of the condensate and the corresponding values of the anisotropy parameter Î»ğœ†italic-lambda\lambda of the external trap.

Figure 1. PoincarÃ¨ Sections of the mz=0subscriptğ‘šğ‘§0italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0m_{z}=0 modes. From left to right: Ï‡=1/5ğœ’15italic-chi RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:5\chi=1/5, 2/525NUMBER:2 MULOP:divide NUMBER:52/5 and 3/535NUMBER:3 MULOP:divide NUMBER:53/5, respectively. Ï‡ğœ’italic-chi\chi is the relative increase of energy with respect to the ground-state. Trap anisotropy Î»=1.501ğœ†1.501italic-lambda RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.501\lambda=1.501.
Figure 2. The same as in Figure 1. Trap anisotropy Î»=8ğœ†8italic-lambda RELOP:equals italic-square-root ARG:start NUMBER:8 ARG:end\lambda=\sqrt{8} (JILA).

Figure 3. Configurations of the (Î»ğœ†italic-lambda\lambda,Ï‡ğœ’italic-chi\chi) plane for which the mz=0subscriptğ‘šğ‘§0italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0m_{z}=0 oscillations are regular. Î»ğœ†italic-lambda\lambda is the trap anisotropy and Ï‡ğœ’italic-chi\chi is the relative increase of energy with respect to the ground-state. Full triangles: MIT trap. Full circles: (3,5,0)350OPEN:( NUMBER:3 PUNCT:, NUMBER:5 PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 CLOSE:)(3,5,0) resonance. Full squares: JILA trap. Open circles: all the other configurations.
